sols_html:
To find the diagonal matrix D, we need to compute the determinant of the matrix A-tI.

\[\begin{aligned} \det(A-tI) &= \det\left(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 2-t & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3-t & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1-t\\ \end{array} \right] \right) \\ &= (3-t)\det\left(\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 2-t & 3 \\ 4 & 1-t \end{array} \right] \right)\\ &= (3-t)\left( (2-t)(1-t) - 12 \right) \\ &= (3-t)(t-5)(t+2)\end{aligned}\]

Which means that eigenvalues are 3, 5 and -2. To find the eigenvectors (which will be the columns of the matrix P), we pick vectors of the kernels of \(A-tI\) where t = 3, 5, -2.

Eigenvalue t = 3.

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 2-3 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3-3 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1-3\\ \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} -1 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & -2\\ \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue t = 3 is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Eigenvalue t = 5.

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 2-5 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3-5 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1-5\\ \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} -3 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & -2 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & -4\\ \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue t = 5 is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Eigenvalue t = -2.

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 2-(-2) & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3-(-2) & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1-(-2)\\ \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 4 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 5 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 3\\ \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus an eigenvector corresponding to the eigenvalue t = -2 is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 0 \\ -4 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

can be chosen as an eigenvector.

So the matrices D and P are given by

\[\begin{aligned} D = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2 \end{array}\right] \quad P = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & -4\\ \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Now, as \(A = PDP^{-1}\), then

\[\begin{aligned} A^{-k} &= \left( PDP^{-1} \right)^{-k}\\ &= PD^{-k}P^{-1} \\ &= P\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2\\ \end{array} \right]^{-k}P^{-1}\\ &= P\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 3^{-k} & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 5^{-k} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & (-2)^{-k}\\ \end{array} \right]P^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

So we can see that as k gets large, \(D^{-k}\) get closers to the zero matrix. Hence the right hand side, and with it the matrix A-k, also approaches the zeros matrix.

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 2 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Find a diagonal matrix D and an invertible matrix P such that \(A = PDP^{-1}\). Do not compute the matrix \(P^{-1}\). Show that \(A^{-k}\) approaches the zero matrix as k becomes very large.
